text: You can still get the old bananas from small farms like Miami Fruit in the US and others around the world. It's just that giant fruit corporations use the new less tasty variety because they don't want to spend a few cents per acre reading the old banana infection in their soil. Because they fixed a monocrop problem by planting a different monocrop though it looks like they're going to have to switch to a 3rd less tasty banana variety.

text: Bananas are wild- the ones we buy in the store are triploids, which means they have 3 copies of each chromosome (we are diploids bc we have 2 copies of each, 1 from mom and 1 from dad). Mother nature doesnt like this, and so store bananas - short story- are "sterile" in the way that they cant interact with other bananas to mutate and have baby bananas. Instead, the reason we do get more bananas is through cloning (asexual repro). Fun fact, this is also (at least 1 of) the reason bananas are "seedless"

text: The islands that grow bananas are pretty much under lockdown to try and stop parasites from entering and killing off the clones of bananas- since they are all identical, if 1 parasite can kill 1 of the bananas in that field the parasite can and will kill all the others (they aren't really mutating, at least not very much, so there aren't any bananas in that field that will have genes that can help them resist or fight against parasites with mutated genes)
